乌克兰的盟友会向其运送更多武器吗？

其军火库与俄罗斯相比仍相形见绌

B拉齐尔曾经是一个小型玉米出口国。然而，在过去的二十年里，今年其在全球出口中的份额预计将超过30%。拉丁美洲各地都有类似的成功故事，该地区在世界农产品中所占的份额越来越大。今年的收成特别丰收，弥补了乌克兰因战争造成的农作物短缺。但下一次的收成可能会少得多。

六月，世界进入了“厄尔尼诺”阶段，这是一种天气现象的三个阶段之一，它使太平洋海水温度升高，并引发世界各地的极端天气事件。过去的厄尔尼诺现象对农业和其他容易受到天气模式变化影响的行业造成了严重破坏。对于像拉丁美洲这样的大宗商品强国来说，这可能会给全球粮食供应带来麻烦。

我们的姊妹公司经济学人智库的分析师认为，厄尔尼诺现象将带来三大变化，影响该地区的产出（见地图）。一些地区将比平均水平干燥；其他人更湿；还有一些人将面临气温飙升的情况。少数不幸的人会同时经历这三者：玻利维亚可能会在全国范围内面临干旱和洪水。

加勒比地区、中美洲、哥伦比亚和墨西哥西部地区尤其容易遭受干旱。今年年底的干燥天气将阻碍农业生产并增加森林火灾的风险。严重依赖降雨的基本谷物、豆类和牲畜将受到最严重的影响。

与此同时，湿润的天气可能会给拉丁美洲干旱地区带来一些缓解。例如，阿根廷肥沃的潘帕斯地区可能会受益于高于平均水平的降雨量。根据世界银行的数据，严重干旱摧毁了该国的农业，该国农业占国内生产总值的 6%。大豆、玉米和小麦这三种在干旱条件下表现尤其糟糕的作物可能会受益于厄尔尼诺现象的降雨。

然而，太多的好事会增加洪水的风险。 EIU预测，秘鲁经济将在明年1月至5月期间受到打击，届时北部海岸的大雨可能会破坏基础设施，并减少农业和渔业产量。洪水已经摧毁了灌溉渠道，并可能给农区带来蝗虫、老鼠和植物病害。过去的厄尔尼诺事件对价格产生了相当大的影响：2017 年 3 月，秘鲁消费者价格环比上涨 1.3%，创 19 年来最大涨幅。

气温的变化将带来更多的挑战。预计巴西中西部地区（该国的农业重镇）将迎来农作物丰收的天气。北部和东北部地区——棉花、玉米和甘蔗的重要产地——可能会遭遇干旱。但巴西东南部往往受益于厄尔尼诺年春季和夏季的充足降雨，这可以提高农业产量。

目前，尽管俄罗斯轰炸乌克兰黑海港口后小麦价格有所上涨，但大多数主要农作物的全球价格仍低于战前水平。世界大部分地区的丰收保证了供应的畅通和价格的稳定。厄尔尼诺现象的回归可能会颠覆这一点。■

; Fri, 21 Jul 2023 19:29:05 GMT /内容/ogahdpdvi3lfmis677ojhhbcpqhhajct https://www.economist.com/graphic-detail/2023/07/21/the-next-threat-to-commodity-prices-will-be-el-nino The hard-right Vox could be in Spain’s next government

除非民调结果非常错误，否则西班牙反对党中右翼人民党 ( PP ) 将在 7 月 23 日的选举中名列第一，轻松领先于执政的社会党。争夺第三和第四的是 Vox（人民党右侧）和 Sumar（社会党左侧）。剩下的将是小团体——主要是地区性政党，包括一些分离主义政党。

这使得西班牙面临两个可能的联合政府。社会党（总理佩德罗·桑切斯领导下）和苏马尔希望组建一个类似于现任政府的少数派政府。但要做到这一点，他们需要许多小人物和分裂主义者的帮助，这将带来尴尬的妥协和潜在的不稳定。更有可能的情况是在 Vox 的支持下组建人民党政府。这将意味着西班牙将成为自 1975 年弗朗西斯科·佛朗哥将军独裁统治结束以来首个将极右派纳入其中的政府——这一前景令国内外许多人感到担忧。

沃克斯是什么？它的反对者称之为法西斯主义。其领导人称这是无法回答其论点的左翼分子所使用的嘘声。 7 月 20 日，西班牙东南部城市穆尔西亚闷热潮湿，举行了一场政党集会，让人们了解了选民的动机。该地区在 2019 年 11 月的选举中给了 Vox 29% 的选票，这是该党在西班牙的最高成绩。

Vox 领导人圣地亚哥·阿巴斯卡尔 (Santiago Abascal) 谴责了对西班牙的一系列威胁：分离主义者（即加泰罗尼亚独立的支持者）；恐怖分子（指巴斯克地区现已解散的埃塔运动）；共产党人；性别意识形态；欧盟官僚；气候变化的“新宗教”；和更多。相比之下，Vox 代表什么？主权、边界和“尊严”，这是阿巴斯卡尔先生经常使用的一个词。但他也呼吁建立“民主国家”、女性“在尊严和权利上与男性平等”以及有序移民（而不是非法移民）。

事实上，Vox 汇集了各种不同的投诉。大约十年前，该党领导人因厌恶人民党对分离主义者表现出的软弱态度而与人民党分道扬镳。但它吸引了贵族和最贫穷选民（在中产阶级中表现最差）、欧盟怀疑论者（西班牙很少有这种怀疑论者）、气候变化否认者、对女权主义变革速度感到震惊的男性、猎人和斗牛爱好者以及那些厌倦了不能自豪地展示西班牙国旗的人的支持。 （他们在穆尔西亚的集会上并没有表现出这样的沉默。）

但当被问及他们最关心的问题时，集会上的一些人回答“安全”。他们很快补充说，他们的意思是控制移民。 Vox 领导人和选民表示，他们支持合法移民，尤其是拉丁裔，他们与西班牙有着相同的母语和多数宗教信仰，并且渴望融入社会。他们说他们只反对非法移民，特别是来自阿拉伯世界和非洲的非法移民。穆尔西亚吸引了许多这样的移民，他们在闷热的条件下在水果和蔬菜田里辛勤劳作。参加集会的 55 岁弗朗西斯科指责他们压低了农业工人的工资。 19 岁的罗克（Roque）正在学习美发，他说很难找到与他们竞争的工作（而且他的女性朋友害怕独自外出）。

这使得 Vox 成为欧洲众多右翼民族主义和民粹主义政党之一，令老牌政党头疼不已。在西班牙，最重要的是人民党领导人阿尔贝托·努涅斯·费霍 (Alberto Núñez Feijóo)。近年来，他将党推向政治中心。这种转变基本上是成功的。但它已经在右边打开了空间。费乔先生几乎肯定会失去多数席位，除非他与 Vox 达成协议。

5 月 28 日的地区选举暗示了 Feijóo 先生的选择。在巴伦西亚和埃斯特雷马杜拉，人民党与 Vox 达成协议，后者赢得了部长职位和正式联盟。但在包括穆尔西亚在内的其他地区，人民党坚持单独组建少数派政府，并得到了外部 Vox 的支持。沃克斯拒绝了。穆尔西亚可能因此将举行新的选举。

西班牙人厌倦了政治冲突。在第一次选举未能组建政府后，他们在 2019 年举行了两次选举，自那以后，地区选举（特别是加泰罗尼亚、卡斯蒂利亚莱昂和安达卢西亚）让他们继续投票和谈论政治。桑切斯领导的少数派联合政府面临的困难加剧了压力。被这些戏剧性事件弄得精疲力尽的选民正在回到两大中间派政党。但仍有足够多的人受到极端新政党的诱惑，以至于恢复稳定的一党政府看起来几乎是不可能的。

这次选举标志着西班牙人首次在欧洲假期高峰期进行投票。每个人都渴望前往海滩或山上的凉爽。但组建联合政府将是一项艰巨的任务。无论谁在周日率先获胜，都没有时间放松并享受胜利。 ■

科学可以阻止生物钟吗？

为什么试管受精不能解决生育危机

总统纳伊布·布克莱在竞选时承诺结束萨尔瓦多的暴力犯罪。在任期间，他在几乎没有证据且没有经过适当审判的情况下监禁了数万名年轻人。他的残酷镇压极大地降低了谋杀率，并为他赢得了公众的青睐，但这付出了怎样的代价呢？ 《经济学人》副主编罗伯特·盖斯特在萨尔瓦多国内报道了布克莱先生持久受欢迎的情况，因为他着手废除对其统治的制衡。

; Fri, 21 Jul 2023 17:00:57 GMT /内容/oh6elo595no96qj1336vtcs5iavhrek8 https://www.economist.com/films/2023/07/21/inside-el-salvadors-war-on-crime Critics are getting less cruel. Alas

很高兴知道一位评论家称约翰济慈的诗歌为“胡言乱语的白痴”。更令人高兴的是，弗吉尼亚·伍尔夫认为詹姆斯·乔伊斯的作品是“垃圾”。当然，当评论家多萝西·帕克（Dorothy Parker）读到《小熊维尼》时，她发现它充满了天真、幼稚的奇思妙想，以至于她——在她自己异想天开的拼写时刻——“哇地一声”，肯定没有人会不高兴。

对于读者来说，生活中没有什么比一篇非常好的、非常差的评论更纯粹的乐趣了。对于作家来说，生活几乎没有比这更纯粹的痛苦了。继帕克之后，AA 米尔恩再也没有写过另一首《小熊维尼奇思妙想》。 “异想天开”这个词对他来说就变得“令人厌恶”。在发表了“胡言乱语”的评论后，济慈欣然倒地而死。拜伦勋爵写道，“被一篇文章扼杀了”。

今天的文学生活很少有如此精彩的场面。打开书评页面，你更有可能看到作家们用“抒情的”、“才华横溢的”和“有洞察力的”这样的词来描述彼此和他们的作品，而不是像他们以前那样，用“令人厌烦的”、“白痴”和“粪堆”。在文学页面上，现在出现了一位作家所说的“地方性”分数膨胀。新闻网站 BuzzFeed 的一位编辑甚至宣布，其图书版块根本不会做负面书评。这对世界各地的作家（和他们的妈妈）来说都是个好消息。对于读者来说，这可不是什么好消息。文学界也许不再需要哀悼被唾弃的诗人；它确实需要哀悼打手的死亡。

很少有人会大声哀叹。批评并不是一种崇高的使命：正如那句老话所说，没有哪个城市曾经为批评家树立过雕像。但也很少有城市为污水工程师或前列腺外科医生竖立雕像。但它们是有用的，就像批评家一样。一个博览群书的人一年可能读20本书左右。相比之下，根据 Nielsen BookData 的数据，去年仅在英国就出版了 153,000 本书。也就是说，平均每天有 420 多本书。去年的作物包括“思考眼泪：十八世纪法国的哭泣和哭泣”、“你的猫是精神病患者吗？”和“大便前先找到厕所”。也许这些书都值得被冠以“有洞察力”这样的称号。看来不太可能。

大多数书确实很糟糕，这在文学界是一个公开的秘密。批评家的工作就是对它们进行填充，首先是身体上的（在书桌上工作，你的第一个、令人深感沮丧的工作将是检查每周交付的一袋袋书），然后是文学上的评论。资深评论家乔治·奥威尔知道评论应该是残酷的。他写道，“在十分之九的情况下，唯一客观真实的批评是‘这本书毫无价值’”，而唯一真实的评论会说，“这本书对我一点也不感兴趣，除非有人付钱给我，否则我不会写它。”

评论很少如此有力。一些出版物保留了强烈批评的传统，但评论往往让人感觉像是一项自鸣得意的内部工作。文学报纸尤其容易出现这种情况。他们往往有很多被称为“费迪南德”的评论家；用“jejune”这样的词；读起来与其说是承诺，不如说是威胁的头条新闻：“索马里向何处去？”、“结构主义被驯化”或（每个人都在谈论的问题）“谁害怕仔细阅读？”相比之下，斧头工作通常选择不那么高调的风格。评论家菲利普·亨舍尔 (Philip Hensher) 在一篇臭名昭著的评论中写道，一位作家太糟糕了，“他无法在墙上写下‘流浪汉’”。

曾经，这样的讽刺在文学页面上很常见。牛津大学英语教授罗伯特·道格拉斯·费尔赫斯特 (Robert Douglas-Fairhurst) 表示，在维多利亚时代，“评论被视为一种文化卫生，因此有很高的标准”。评论家不仅是在攻击敌人，而且是在净化文学的神圣殿堂。但这并不能阻止他们自己变得肮脏。例如，一位评论家称一位作家同事的作品为“肮脏的垃圾”；可靠、稳健的阿尔弗雷德·丁尼生（Alfred Tennyson）称这又是“文学锁上的虱子”。而约翰·弥尔顿（显然又暂时失去了天堂）则将另一个人描述为“顽固的大桶”。

挥舞你的武器

尽管这种过激行为很有趣，但最致命的评论往往更加微妙。英国作家兼评论家亚当·马斯-琼斯（Adam Mars-Jones）观察到，最好的差评不是斧头活，而是手术刀活，“因为如果不精确，那就行不通。”维多利亚时代的人也挥舞着手术刀。乔治·艾略特在夏洛特·勃朗特的《简·爱》中运用了其中最出色的手法之一。艾略特写道：“我希望剧中人物的谈话不要像警察报告中的男女主人公那样。”

现代评论家很少能达到如此致命的美感。评论常常充满了填充词：“黑暗有趣”、“灼热”、“深刻的冥想”。其中许多（请读者注意）都是“无聊”一词的委婉说法，实际上在文学页面上是被禁止的。于是就有了“详细”（“无聊”）； “详尽”（“真的很无聊”）； “权威”（“无聊，但是是一位教授写的，我没有完成，所以不能批评它”）。等等。

互联网是这种软化的原因之一。它改变了批评的经济性（缩小的报纸的书页更少，因此编辑们倾向于用你应该读的书来填充它们，而不是那些你不应该读的书）和批评的可取性（那些看起来很有趣的侮辱在网上永远回响时脱口而出）。聘请专业审稿人的趋势也无济于事。如果你是世界上两位早期苏美尔楔形文字专家之一，而你对世界上另一位专家给出了差评，那么你可能会觉得有趣 20 分钟，但会遗憾 20 年。

互联网也有助于减少匿名性。曾经，大多数评论都没有署名，让评论者感觉就像一个默默无闻的推特巨魔一样。如今，大多数评论者不仅会被点名，而且很容易被搜索到，而且还会受到侮辱。作家兼评论家 DJ 泰勒 (DJ Taylor) 表示，30 年前，评论家“心照不宣地受到鼓励，真正对别人发起攻击”，而现在，人们“害怕冒犯他人”，以免 Twitter 上的大量关注。

有人试图重新提出尖锐的批评。 2012 年，两位评论家（其中一位现在在《经济学人》工作）发起了一项名为“年度最佳斧头工作”的奖项作为“反对迟钝、顺从和懒惰思维的十字军”。它运行了三年。其联合创始人之一弗勒·麦克唐纳 (Fleur Macdonald) 认为，“文学界现在可能比以往任何时候都更需要它”，但由于“糟糕的书评是有争议的”，它很难重振旗鼓并获得赞助。

斧头仍然偶尔会出现，不是针对第一本书或不知名作者的作品（这被认为是毫无意义和残酷的），而是针对足够著名的作家进行攻击。哈里王子的《备用》几乎遭到普遍批评。这对作家来说可能是一种痛苦。小说家安东尼·鲍威尔认为人们要么是“粉丝”，要么是“狗屎”，而罗马作家卡图卢斯最著名的诗之一是对批评他女性化的批评者的回击。卡图卢斯写道：“Pedicabo ego vos et irrumabo”，意思是（广义上）：“我会鸡奸你并用脸操你。”这可不是你现在在《泰晤士报文学副刊》上看到的那种东西。

因此刀片的闪光更少。但它们仍应偶尔闪烁。可以忘记的是，评论的真正市场不是评论家或作者。是读者。泰勒先生说，他们仍然想知道“是否应该花 15.99 英镑买一本书。”批评家有“责任”说实话。此外，如果作者不喜欢，他们毕竟是作家。他们可以像卡图卢斯那样做出回应。不过，如果他们想在 BuzzFeed 上发表文章，他们可能会决定少说脏话。 ■

; Fri, 21 Jul 2023 16:25:18 GMT /内容/5bhilktlf182ojl9citgklf9c7iuoq9i https://www.economist.com/podcasts/2023/07/21/how-would-a-second-trump-term-be- Different-from-the-first Voters give Britain’s ruling Conservatives a historic mauling

凯尔·斯塔默爵士位于伦敦北部的家中的访客报告称，他们发现了一个忧心忡忡的人。这位工党领袖对他将如何组织唐宁街以及他的一些幕僚的政府能力感到担忧。最重要的是，他担心自己根本无法到达那里。他的政党在民意调查中保持广泛且持续的领先优势，这让他的许多同事兴高采烈地表示，他们将在明年举行选举后在政府任职。然而，凯尔爵士本人认为这种做法过于傲慢。 “人们正在关注民意调查。这是一个很大、很大、很大的错误，”他本周早些时候说道。

7 月 20 日保守党占据席位的三场议会补选结果可以作为政治罗夏墨迹测试：足以增强基尔爵士的希望和恐惧。保守党在其中两次选举中惨败：塞尔比和安斯蒂（北约克郡）击败工党，萨默顿和弗罗姆（萨默塞特）击败自由民主党。这些因素共同表明保守党可能会遭遇压倒性失败。但是，与这种说法相矛盾的是，执政党以微弱优势保住了第三个席位：位于伦敦西郊的乌克斯布里奇和南莱斯利普。总理里希·苏纳克 (Rishi Sunak) 表示，乌克斯布里奇的结果表明大选尚未“板上钉钉”。这看起来也像是一个有利于环境的政策在投票箱中遭到强烈反对的案例。

这三场竞选是保守党执政13年后萎靡不振的一个症状。前首相鲍里斯·约翰逊 (Boris Johnson) 于 6 月 9 日辞去了在乌克斯布里奇 (Uxbridge) 的席位，此前议会一个委员会认定他在 Partygate 丑闻中撒了谎。他的亲密盟友奈杰尔·亚当斯（Nigel Adams）第二天辞去塞尔比议员职务。大卫·沃伯顿因吸毒（他承认）和不当性行为（他否认）的指控而在萨默顿辞职。

两个席位出现大幅波动，远远超过大选中实现政府更迭所需的席位。在塞尔比，25 岁​​的凯尔·马瑟（Keir Mather，与凯尔爵士一起）推翻了保守党的 20,137 票多数票。近24个百分点的摇摆是自1994年达德利·韦斯特竞选以来最大的保守党对工党的转变，当时是1997年大选惨败之前的一次。（这也是自1945年以来第二大的此类转变。）基尔爵士说，这一结果反映了选民在政府混乱和生活成本压力下要求“变革”的要求。通货膨胀已开始放缓，但 6 月份仍达到 7.9%。

在萨默顿，自由民主党以 29 个百分点的优势战胜保守党，这是自 1945 年以来对保守党的第五大支持，也是自 2019 年大选以来第四次补选胜利。这表明自由民主党已经恢复了其历史形态，成为在补选中夺取保守党席位的机器。它还表明该党也在英格兰西南部历史悠久的乡村中心地带恢复元气。最近，自由民主党在伦敦附近较富裕的通勤城镇也出现了激增。

结果显示，鉴于反保守党选民倾向于进行更多（且更高效）的战术投票，保守党陷入了困境。工党在萨默顿的得票率下降了10.3个百分点；自由民主党在塞尔比的得票率下降了 5.3 个百分点 “对于保守党议员来说，除了他们的政党仍然深陷选举困境之外，得出任何其他结论似乎都是不明智的，”斯特拉斯克莱德大学政治学家约翰·柯蒂斯爵士表示。

然而该党在阿克斯布里奇的成功可能会鼓励它这样做。两党都认为工党的失败是由于保守党反对扩大伦敦超低排放区（ ULEZ ）造成的。它对不符合排放标准的汽车每天征收 12.50 英镑（16 美元）的费用，主要包括车龄超过 8 年的柴油车或车龄超过 18 年的汽油车。该区域目前覆盖伦敦内城区，将于 8 月 29 日扩大三倍以覆盖该市的外围行政区。但乌克斯布里奇严重依赖汽车，而保守党竞选活动则以伦敦工党市长萨迪克·汗及其政党对首都外围地区的担忧漠不关心为比喻。

双方得出的结论是，工党在民意调查中长期确立的全国领先地位可能会在短期竞选活动中通过针对他们选择的热点问题进行积极的竞选活动而被破坏。尽管在政府任职十多年，保守党已经完善了表现得像叛乱反对派的伎俩，并在这种情况下成功地将竞争从对约翰逊的公投变成了对汗先生的公投。

阿克斯布里奇的这场运动是保守党更广泛的环境战略的一部分。政府骑着两匹马。它支持脱碳，并承诺在核电和碳捕获技术上花费数十亿英镑。然而，它也将工党描绘成绿色抗议者“生态犯罪暴徒”的受害者，他们会危及能源安全，并会中断体育赛事。保守党右翼立即抓住这一结果作为证据，证明气候政策将对个人选民造成越来越大的压力，例如计划逐步淘汰汽油车和燃气锅炉，这对选举是有毒的。类似乌克斯布里奇的活动可能会成为一种固定活动。

阿克斯布里奇的结果最终将支持工党忧心忡忡的一派，并为保守党自满的一方提供支持。它将加强那些与工党领袖关系密切的人的势力，他们希望剥夺宣言中任何可能令选民震惊的承诺。 （党内人士将于本周末开会，充实政策平台。）工党已经缩减了每年在脱碳方面花费 280 亿英镑的计划，称该法案太高了。与此同时，那些热衷于在绿色问题上进行下一次选举的保守党人面临着抓住伦敦外区选举结果的风险，而无法就该党在塞尔比和萨默顿的糟糕表现提出尖锐的问题。 ■

; Fri, 21 Jul 2023 16:03:05 GMT /内容/ntrq7k4rh9nt363hs7a8f2in9qjehpii https://www.economist.com/britain/2023/07/21/voters-give-britains-ruling-conservatives-a-historic-mauling How two new munitions could affect the war in Ukraine

首先是坦克。然后是战斗机。然后是集束炸弹。自俄罗斯于 2022 年 2 月入侵以来，乌克兰已经获得了西方盟友起初不愿提供的一系列硬件。其愿望清单上剩下的两个项目是一对用于远程精确轰炸的武器：名字笨重的GLSDB （或地面发射小直径炸弹）和ATACMS （陆军战术导弹系统，发音为“attack-ems”）。美国已承诺向乌克兰发送GLSDB ，但尚未抵达。乌克兰也曾要求获得ATACMS ，但其请求尚未获得批准。这些武器有什么能力，它们会如何影响乌克兰疲软的反攻？

从GLSDB开始。该系统由一枚火箭组成，一枚带有弹出式机翼的滑翔机炸弹在高空分离。据与美国波音公司一起生产这种弹药的瑞典国防承包商萨博公司称，其重达 113 公斤的破片弹头可以“击中汽车轮胎半径内”，最远可达 150 公里。 GLSDB是从HIMARS等移动发射装置发射的，HIMARS是乌克兰去年收到的一种美国系统。乌克兰目前使用这些发射器发射的火箭弹最大射程为84公里，略高于GLSDB的一半。除了更大的射程外，新弹药还具有可编程引信，其选项包括空中爆炸（这意味着它会在空中引爆，例如杀死更多步兵）和延迟引爆（例如，在穿透混凝土结构后发生）。

GLSDB可以在飞行中进行机动，因此它们可以击中不同区域的目标，而无需重新定位发射器。萨博声称，这种弹药可以摧毁山坡“反坡”上无法被直接火力击中的目标。 GLSDB的GPS制导由机载惯性导航提供支持， 不受干扰。现在这一点很重要，因为俄罗斯电子战正在对一些乌克兰武器的制导造成问题。

ATACMS也通过移动火箭发射器发射。它比GLSDB更老，美国军队在 1991 年的海湾战争中首次使用。尽管也使用 GPS 和惯性导航，但ATACMS 的精确度不如GLSDB 。但其 227 公斤的破片弹头重量是其两倍，这意味着它们可以造成更大的伤害。而且它可以飞行300公里，是GLSDB航程的两倍。

在这两者中， ATACMS可能对乌克兰有更大的帮助，因为乌克兰迫切需要能够进行远程打击的武器。其为数不多的载人战机很容易受到俄罗斯防空系统的攻击，这使得深入攻击的风险极高。在早期遭受损失后，俄罗斯军队已将许多弹药库移至距离前线更远的地方，使许多武器无法进入。 ATACMS将使乌克兰能够打击俄罗斯占领的所有领土上的目标，包括2014年夺取的克里米亚半岛。它可以用来打击俄罗斯的补给线，包括连接克里米亚和俄罗斯的铁路和公路刻赤大桥，该大桥已被不明手段击中两次。

当然，即使是航程较短的GLSDB也会成为乌克兰火力的一个受欢迎的补充。但尚不清楚其军队何时能得到它们。美国2月份表示将提供这些弹药，但6月22日，五角大楼一名官员告诉国会，第一批弹药不会在秋季之前抵达。一种担忧是供应似乎有限。据报道，美国向乌克兰提供GLSDB的计划将推迟向台湾提供该武器。 ATACMS在与朝鲜的任何战争中都非常重要。但即使物资充足，白宫也担心事态升级。乌克兰承诺不会向俄罗斯发射美国武器。美国总统乔·拜登尚未被说服。当 7 月 12 日被问到时，他淡化了这个问题：“他们现在已经拥有了ATACMS的同等产品。” ■

; Fri, 21 Jul 2023 15:26:20 GMT /内容/7v4j8nkvd2m67j2sf9if8ejg8cqlkg89 https://www.economist.com/the-economist-explains/2023/07/21/how-two-new-munitions-could-affect-the-war-in-ukraine One of the “godfathers of AI” airs his concerns

人工智能 ( AI ) 的研究将走向何方？这对人类来说都是有益的，还是存在足够大的风险，需要我们付出更多努力来了解它们并制定对策？我相信后者是正确的。

人脑是一台生物机器，因此建造至少具有同样智能的机器应该是可行的。正如杰夫·辛顿 (Geoff Hinton) 所说，一旦我们理解了人类智能的主要原理，我们将能够构建在大多数任务上超越我们的超人人工智能。Yann LeCun 和我在 2018 年因人工智能方面的工作与他分享了图灵奖。

计算机在围棋或蛋白质结构建模等专业领域已经超越了我们，而且我们正在构建更通用的人工智能系统方面取得进展：聊天GPT可以快速处理来自互联网的庞大训练语料库，而这项任务需要人类花费数万辈子的时间来专门阅读。这是可以实现的，因为在学习时，计算机可以执行广泛的并行计算，并以比人类快数十亿倍的速度在它们之间共享数据，而人类只能使用语言每秒交换几位。此外，与人类不同，计算机程序是不朽的，能够像计算机病毒一样被复制或自我复制。

我们什么时候可以期待这样超人的人工智能？直到最近，我将 50% 的置信区间置于几十年到一个世纪之间。自GPT -4 以来，我将我的估计修正为几年到几十年，我的图灵奖共同获得者也同意这一观点。如果五年后发生怎么办？甚至十个？ Open AI , the company behind GPT , is among those who think it could happen by then.

Are we prepared for this possibility? Do we comprehend the potential consequences? No matter the potential benefits, disregarding or playing down catastrophic risks would be very unwise.

How might such catastrophes arise? There are always misguided or ill-intentioned people, so it seems highly probable that at least one organisation or person would—intentionally or not—misuse a powerful tool once it became widely available.

We are not there yet, but imagine a scenario where a method for achieving superhuman AI becomes publicly known and the model downloadable and usable with the resources accessible to a mid-sized company, as is currently the case with open-source—but fortunately not superhuman—large language models. What are the chances that at least one such organisation would download the model and instruct it, possibly using a natural language interface like Chat GPT , to achieve goals that would violate human rights, undermine democracy or threaten humanity as a whole? Examples include targeted cyber-attacks that could threaten fragile supply chains, using convincing dialogue and AI -generated videos to influence citizens to sway an election, or designing and deploying bioweapons.

Another possibility is that AI acquires a self-preservation tendency. This could happen in many ways: training it to mimic humans (who exhibit self-preservation); instructions from humans that make it seek power, and hence pursue self-preservation as a subsidiary goal; or a “Frankenstein” scenario, where someone intentionally builds an AI system with a survival instinct, to make the AI in their own image.

New entities with self-preservation are like new species: to preserve themselves, these AI s would strive to prevent humans from shutting them down, attempt to replicate themselves in multiple locations as a defensive measure and potentially behave in ways that harm humans. Once another species on Earth surpasses us in intelligence and power, we may lose control over our own future.

But could such a rogue AI shape the real world? If, like Auto GPT , it was connected to the internet, it could develop numerous strategies or learn them from us: exploiting cyber-security vulnerabilities, employing human assistants (including organised crime), creating accounts to generate income (for instance in financial markets), and influencing or using extortion against key decision-makers. A superhuman AI , whether of its own volition or following human instructions, could destabilise democracies, disrupt supply chains, invent new weapons or worse.

Even if we knew how to construct AI that was not prone to developing dangerous objectives, and even if we implemented strong regulations to minimise access and enforce safety protocols, there is still a possibility of someone getting in, ignoring the protocols and instructing the AI with disastrous consequences. Given these risks, and the challenges around regulating AI safely, I believe it is crucial to act swiftly on three fronts.

First, the world's governments and legislatures must adopt national rules, and co-ordinate international ones, that safeguard the public against all AI -related harms and risks. These should prohibit the development and deployment of AI systems with dangerous capabilities; and require thorough evaluation of potential harm with independent audits, with at least the same level of scrutiny as that applied to the pharmaceutical, aviation and nuclear industries.

Second, they should accelerate AI safety and governance research to better understand options for robust safety protocols and governance, and how best to protect human rights and democracy.

Third, we need to research and develop countermeasures in case dangerous AI s arise, whether they are under human instruction or have developed their own goals to preserve themselves. Such research should be co-ordinated internationally and under an appropriate governance umbrella, to make sure that the countermeasures can be deployed around the world and that this work has no military aims, reducing the risk of an AI arms race. This research, combining national-security and AI expertise, should be done by neutral and autonomous entities across several countries (to avoid capture by a single government, which could use its control of AI technology to keep itself in power or attack other countries). It should not be entrusted solely to national labs or for-profit organisations, whose parochial or commercial objectives might interfere with the mission of defending humanity as a whole.

Considering the immense potential for damage, we should make investments to safeguard our future comparable to, if not exceeding, past investments in the space programme or current investments in nuclear fusion. Much is being spent on improving AI capabilities. It is crucial that we invest at least as much in protecting humanity. ■

Yoshua Bengio is a professor at the the Université de Montréal and founder and scientific director of Mila - Quebec AI Institute.

For a contrary view on AI and existential risk, see this article by Blake Richards, Dhanya Sridhar, Guillaume Lajoie and Blaise Agüera y Arcas.

; Fri, 21 Jul 2023 14:38:10 GMT /content/9e6ej57gpm5q26ho13p5ed7gfi9itnu3 https://www.economist.com/by-invitation/2023/07/21/one-of-the-godfathers-of-ai-airs-his-concerns Fears about AI’s existential risk are overdone, says a group of experts

I N THE PAST year, as the startling capabilities of artificial intelligence ( AI ) have emerged into public view, attention has been drawn to the existential risk, or “x-risk”, that the technology may pose. The concern is that computers endowed with superhuman intelligence might destroy most or all human life. The majority of researchers raising the alarm are sincerely motivated by concern about AI -related risks, present and future. However, calls to action to mitigate superintelligent- AI x-risk may both impede the development of beneficial uses of AI —of which there are many—and distract regulators, the public, companies and other researchers from addressing important shorter-term risks.

Superintelligence is not required for AI to cause harm. That is already happening. AI is used to violate privacy, create and spread disinformation, compromise cyber-security and build biased decision-making systems. The prospect of military misuse of AI is imminent. Today's AI systems help repressive regimes to carry out mass surveillance and to exert powerful forms of social control. Containing or reducing these contemporary harms is not only of immediate value, but is also the best bet for easing potential, albeit hypothetical. future x-risk.

It is safe to say that the AI which exists today is not superintelligent. But it is possible that AI will be made superintelligent in the future. Researchers are divided on how soon that may happen, or even if it will. Still, today's AI models are impressive, and arguably possess a form of intelligence and understanding of the world; otherwise they would not be so useful. Yet they are also easily fooled, liable to generate falsehoods and sometimes fail to reason correctly. As a result, many contemporary harms stem from AI ’s limitations, rather than its capabilities.

It is far from obvious whether AI , superintelligent or not, is best thought of as an alien entity with its own agency or as part of the anthropogenic world, like any other technology that both shapes and is shaped by humans. But for the sake of argument, let us assume that at some point in the future a superintelligent AI emerges which interacts with humanity under its own agency, as an intelligent non-biological organism. Some x-risk-boosters suggest that such an AI would cause human extinction by natural selection, outcompeting humanity with its superior intelligence.

Intelligence surely plays a role in natural selection. But extinctions are not the outcomes of struggles for dominance between “higher” and “lower” organisms. Rather, life is an interconnected web, with no top or bottom (consider the virtual indestructibility of the cockroach). Symbiosis and mutualism—mutually beneficial interaction between different species—are common, particularly when one species depends on another for resources. And in this case, AI s depend utterly on humans. From energy and raw materials to computer chips, manufacturing, logistics and network infrastructure, we are as fundamental to AI s' existence as oxygen-producing plants are to ours.

Perhaps computers could eventually learn to provide for themselves, cutting humans out of their ecology? This would be tantamount to a fully automated economy, which is probably neither a desirable nor an inevitable outcome, with or without superintelligent AI . Full automation is incompatible with current economic systems and, more importantly, may be incompatible with human flourishing under any economic regime—recall the dystopia of Pixar's “ Wall-E ”.

Luckily, the path to automating away all human labour is long. Each step offers a bottleneck (from the AI s' perspective) at which humans can intervene. In contrast, the information-processing labour which AI can perform at next to no cost poses both great opportunity and an urgent socioeconomic challenge.

Some may still argue that AI x-risk, even if improbable, is so dire that prioritising its mitigation is paramount. This echoes Pascal's wager, the 17th-century philosophical argument which held that it was rational to believe in God, just in case he was real, so as to avoid any possibility of the terrible fate of being condemned to hell. Pascal's wager, both in its original and AI versions, is designed to end reasoned debate by assigning infinite costs to uncertain outcomes.

In a utilitarian analysis, in which costs are multiplied by probabilities, infinity times any probability other than zero is still infinity. Hence accepting the AI x-risk version of Pascal's wager might lead us to conclude that AI research should be stopped altogether or tightly controlled by governments. This could curtail the nascent field of beneficial AI , or create cartels with a stranglehold on AI innovation. For example, if governments passed laws limiting the legal right to deploy large generative language models like Chat GPT and Bard to only a few companies, those companies could amass unprecedented (and undemocratic) power to shape social norms, and the ability to extract rent on digital tools that are likely to be critical to the 21st-century economy.

Perhaps regulations could be designed so as to reduce the potential for x-risk while also attending to more immediate AI harms? Probably not; proposals to curb AI x-risk are often in tension with those directed at existing AI harms. For instance, regulations to limit the open-source release of AI models or datasets make sense if the goal is to prevent the emergence of an autonomous networked AI beyond human control. However, such restrictions may handicap other regulatory processes, for instance those for promoting transparency in AI systems or preventing monopolies. In contrast, regulation which takes aim at concrete, short-term risks—such as requiring AI systems to honestly disclose information about themselves—will also help to mitigate longer-term, and even existential, risks.

Regulators should not prioritise existential risk posed by superintelligent AI . Instead, they should address the problems which are in front of them, making models safer and their operations more predictable in line with human needs and norms. Regulations should focus on preventing inappropriate deployment of AI . And political leaders should reimagine a political economy which promotes transparency, competition, fairness and the flourishing of humanity through the use of AI . That would go a long way to curbing today's AI risks, and be a step in the right direction in mitigating more existential, albeit hypothetical, risks. ■

Blaise Agüera y Arcas is a Fellow at Google Research, where he leads a team working on artificial intelligence. ; Fri, 21 Jul 2023 14:27:12 GMT /content/kkfskn7pr7fqm7a7vd67ic8a9ormdstd https://www.economist.com/by-invitation/2023/07/21/fears-about-ais-existential-risk-are-overdone-says-a-group-of-experts At the women’s World Cup, mothers are flourishing

T HE CURRENT generation of American women footballers have already struck one significant blow for equality. In 2022 they forced US Soccer, their governing body, to agree to pay those in the national team as much as their male peers, and to fork out $24m in back pay. At the Women's World Cup, which began in New Zealand on July 20th, several members of the team want to tackle another of the sport's shibboleths: motherhood.

Until recently a football career and motherhood were considered incompatible, by both governing bodies and the footballers themselves. In 2017 a survey of more than 3,000 female players by FIFPRO , the players' union, found that only 2% were mothers. Around 45% said that they planned to retire early in order to have a family. It is easy to understand why. Wages for everyone outside elite clubs are low. And back then there were no specific workplace protections—or even any guidelines—covering how clubs or national associations should treat women footballers who wanted to start families.

That began to change in 2019, when the female players' associations in Spain and Argentina approached FIFPRO to find out what the rules were. According to FIFPRO ’s senior counsel, Alexandra Gómez Bruinewoud, the union had a clear idea of what protections should exist but no documentation. A year of rapid negotiations with FIFA , the sport's governing body, produced a basic set of rules by which all national associations have to abide. These include offering a minimum of 14 weeks of maternity leave, of which at least eight must be taken after the birth. Teams must provide full pay during pregnancy (regardless of when the mother-to-be stops playing) and at least two-thirds of salary once maternity leave begins. Clubs are also banned from ending a player's registration, unless she consents to be replaced temporarily.

It did not take long for the rules to be tested. In early 2021 Sara Bjork Gunnarsdottir, an Icelandic midfielder, got pregnant. Her club, Lyon in France, was one of Europe's most successful. But it had never had a mother on its roster. Ms Bjork said she struck an agreement with the club to spend the second half of her pregnancy at home in Iceland, and resume her playing career once her baby was born. But after two months away she stopped receiving her wages. Lyon told her that under French law it was not obliged to pay her. It backed down only after FIFPRO successfully appealed to FIFA on Ms Bjork's behalf, in May 2022. That one of the world's prestigious clubs was either unaware of or dismissive of the regulations shows that football is yet to complete its reckoning with motherhood.

America's 23-woman squad contains three mums, Crystal Dunn, Julie Ertz and Alex Morgan (pictured), all of whom have spoken openly on the subject. All have brought their children to the tournament. After all, they insist, the football field is no different from any other place of work; family life often runs alongside it. Thirty years ago, two mothers in the American team had to petition US Soccer to pay for a nanny to accompany the squad. Now the federation must pay for flights, accommodation and meals for children aged up to six and their caregivers.

The American mothers, all of whom have over 100 international caps, are able to lobby on behalf of those further down the footballing pyramid. Although the FIFPRO regulations apply to all professional clubs, as Ms Bjork found out compliance can be patchy. The union wants the rules stiffened. It recommends increasing post-birth maternity leave from eight weeks to 12. It also notes that provisions do not apply to adoptive parents or those having children via a surrogate. Last, it wants protection for players whose contracts expire during the maternity period. The financial precarity of most of women's football means that multi-year contracts are much less common than in the men's game.

The pace of change may be gradual, but the work of players like Ms Morgan is beginning to normalise motherhood in the game. Few clubs have yet to figure out how best to support a star who becomes a mother—in the way they might, for example, plan for integrating a foreign player or one recovering from a long-term injury. But the visibility and on-field success of the mothers at the World Cup will force football into change, however reluctantly. ■
